stem: A 32-year-old G2P1 client has just experienced spontaneous rupture of membranes (SROM). Immediately after, the fetal heart rate (FHR) drops to 70 bpm. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: At 09:15, acute fetal bradycardia was noted immediately following spontaneous rupture of membranes. The FHR dropped to 70 bpm.
Background: The client is a 32-year-old G2P1 at term. Cervical exam reveals 6 cm dilation, 80% effacement, and -2 station. The amniotic fluid was clear and copious.
Assessment: Continuous FHR monitoring shows persistent bradycardia at 70 bpm with minimal variability. A vaginal examination reveals a soft, pulsating loop palpable ahead of the fetal head, suggestive of umbilical cord prolapse. Maternal vital signs are stable: BP 118/72, HR 88.
Recommendation: Prepare the client for immediate surgical delivery (C-section) to alleviate fetal distress. Maintain manual elevation of the fetal presenting part to relieve pressure on the umbilical cord until delivery.

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content:
Maternal: BP 118/72, HR 88 bpm, Temp 98.6°F (37°C), RR 18.
Fetal: HR 70 bpm (Bradycardia).

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content: CBC and Coagulation panel are pending. Kleihauer-Betke test to be ordered after delivery if indicated.

tabs.title: Radiology
tabs.content: No radiology orders at this time.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: Currently no medications ordered. Anticipating orders for antibiotics post-delivery and pain management.

actionOptions.text: Keep gloved fingers in the vagina to manually elevate the presenting part off the cord
Position the client in the Knee-Chest or Trendelenburg position
Perform a rapid Leopold maneuver to turn the baby
Instruct the client to push vigorously to deliver the cord first

parameterOptions.text: Maternal oxygenation and status of cord pulsations
Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose
Presence of a positive Babinski sign

rationale.correct: This is an Umbilical Cord Prolapse (c2). When the membranes rupture while the fetal head is at a high station (-2), the cord can wash down ahead of the head. As the head descends, it compresses the cord, causing severe bradycardia (70 bpm). Priority #1 is maintaining your hand in the vagina to push the head UP and off the cord (a1). This relieves pressure on the umbilical cord, restoring blood flow to the fetus. Priority #2 is using gravity (Knee-Chest/Trendelenburg) (a2) to keep the fetus away from the pelvis. This further reduces cord compression. Monitoring focuses on the FHR (p1) to assess fetal well-being and cord pulsations (p2) to ensure adequate blood flow through the cord.
clinicalPearls: DO NOT remove your hand. If you find a prolapsed cord, you are going to the OR with that patient, and your hand stays there until the surgeon says otherwise.
If the cord is protruding from the vagina, don't try to shove it back in; wrap it in warm, saline-soaked sterile gauze to prevent vasospasm.
Call for help immediately, but keep your hand in place.

questionTrap.trap: Removing the hand to find a wedge or go get the doctor.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: If you remove the hand, the head will crush the cord and the baby will die. Call for help with your VOICE, but keep the hand in place.

mnemonic.title: Cord Care
mnemonic.expansion: C-Call for help. O-Off (Get head off cord). R-Reposition (Knee-Chest). D-Deliver fast (C-section).
